    • CloudAudit Definitions
    • Cloudtrail
      • Service Disabled
    • EC2
      • TCP port open
      • Security Group contains IP address
      • Security group contains a port range
      • Security group allows unrestricted traffic
    • ELB
      • ELB is using old SSL policy
    • IAM
      • Active user Access Key not rotated
      • Passwords not set to expire
      • Inactive user Access Key not rotated
      • Password policy doesn't exist
      • Multiple active access keys
      • MFA not enabled
      • Root MFA not enabled
      • Root user has active password
      • Root user has active Access Key
      • Users can reuse old passwords
      • Unused or empty IAM group
      • Account using inline policies
    • RDS
      • RDS is Publicly Accessible
      • RDS short backup retention
      • RDS no automatic upgrades
    • Redshift
      • Cluster data not encrypted
      • Redshift connections not SSL
      • User activity logging disabled
      • Automatic upgrades not enabled
      • Cluster is publicly accessible
      • Redshift TCP port open
    • S3
      • All users can list bucket
      • All users can write to bucket
      • All users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can read bucket
      • All AWS users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can write to bucket
      • Bucket logging not enabled
      • Bucket policy uses IP addresses
      • Bucket policy world All permissions
      • Bucket policy world can Delete
      • Bucket policy world can Get
      • Bucket policy world can List
      • Bucket policy world can Put

    Redshift default TCP port 5439 is open to the world

    Redshift default TCP port 5439 is open, potentially to the world.
    Edit me

    Detail

    The Redshift default TCP port 5439 is open, potentially to the world.

    In order to prevent unauthorized users from gaining privileged access to your virtual server and planting malware or stealing data, you need to make sure that important ports/protocols are only accessible by trusted IP addresses and networks. For example, remote administration ports like 22 (SSH) and 3389 (RDP) should only allow access from your private network or bastion hosts, and not the entire Internet (which is specified in security groups as 0.0.0.0/0).In addition to remote administration ports 22 and 3389, there are several other ports that allow privileged or database access. Make sure you restrict these ports to IPs or subnets you trust, and don’t allow public Internet access (0.0.0.0/0) to them.

    • Ports 20, 21, 22, 23 are checked to see if they are open at all (even privately), including being open to the world (0.0.0.0/0).
    • Ports 1433, 1521, 27017, 3306, 3389, 5432, 5439 are checked to see if they are open to the world (0.0.0.0/0).
      https://aws.amazon.com/articles/1233/

    Suggested Action

    Security Groups can be used to secure ports over TCP, UDP, and ICMP protocols. We recommend that you open only those ports that must be open for your service to operate. Consider deleting or modifying the affected security group. https://aws.amazon.com/articles/1233/

    Additional Information

    Here is a list of some of the common ports you should consider locking down:
    * 22 (SSH)
    * 23 (Telnet)
    * 20/21 (FTP)
    * 1433 (MS-SQL)
    * 1434 (MS-SQL Monitor)
    * 1521 (Oracle)
    * 3389 (RDP)
    * 3306 (MySQL)
    * 3389 (MS Terminal Server-RDP)
    * 4333 (MSQL)
    * 5432 (Postgres)
    * 5439 (Redshift)
    * 5500 (VNC-RDP)
    * 27017 (MongoDB)
